document.docTitle: Rediscovery of the elusive moray Gymnothorax polyuranodon (Teleostei: Muraenidae) from Sri Lanka after 84 years

emphasis.docTitle:
Rediscovery of the elusive moray
Gymnothorax polyuranodon
(Teleostei: Muraenidae ) from Sri Lanka after 84 years

subSection.paragraph: HIRANYA SUDASINGHE 1,2 , THARINDU RANASINGHE 3 & LUKAS RÜBER 2,4

1 Division of Evolutionary Ecology, Institute of Ecology and Evolution, University of
Bern , 3012 Bern , Switzerland
Ễ
hsudasinghe@gmail.com ; https://orcid.org/ 0000-0003-0994-3462

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Naturhistorisches Museum Bern , Bernastrasse, 15, 3005 Bern , Switzerland
Wild Island Foundation, 6A, Mendis Lane, Moratuwa, 10400, Sri Lanka

subSection.paragraph:
4 Division of Aquatic Ecology and Evolution, Institute of Ecology and Evolution, University of
Bern , 3012 Bern , Switzerland
Ễ
lukas.ruber@nmbe.ch ; https://orcid.org/ 0000-0003-0125-008X

Morays of the genus
Gymnothorax
are the most speciose of the Muraenidae . The genus consists of some 140 described species distributed in the Atlantic , Pacific , and Indian Oceans (
Fricke et al. 2023
). While almost all the members of
Gymnothorax
are obligatorily marine, adults of a single species,
Gymnothorax polyuranodon (Bleeker)
, occupy freshwaters (
Ebner et al. 2011
, 2016 ) and low salinity environments (
Ebner et al. 2020
). Originally described from Seram (formerly Ceram) in eastern Indonesia ,
G. polyuranodon
has been reported from countries bordering the tropical Indo-Pacific , from Indonesia to Fiji , including the wet tropics of Australia (
Fricke et al. 2023
). Using the Strontium / Calcium ratio of otoliths from four specimens (with a total length ranging from 275 to 344 mm ) obtained from freshwater locations approximately 13 km upstream of a river mouth in Fiji ,
Tsukamoto et al. (2014)
verified the presence of a larval marine phase in
G. polyuranodon
, succeeded by an estuarine or freshwater phase post-metamorphosis. Studies in Australia suggests that
G. polyuranodon
could inhabit freshwaters all year round; adults are in fact most frequently encountered in freshwaters above the tidal influence (
Ebner et al. 2011
, 2016 ).

Gymnothorax polyuranodon
was first recorded from Sri Lanka by Deraniyagala (1937) . This specimen had been caught with hook and line in 1936, from a 30 m deep pool at Kahangama on the Kalu River, about 57 km inland of the river mouth, well above the tidal influence ( Fig. 1A ). An additional specimen had been captured in 1937 from Dodangoda on the Gin River, about 10 km from the sea ( Deraniyagala 1952 ). Both these rivers drain the lowland rainforests of the island’s perhumid south-western quarter. Since then, efforts by Pethiyagoda (1991) to capture this species from the localities reported by Deraniyagala (1952) proved abortive. Here we report the rediscovery of
G. polyuranodon
from Sri Lanka after a lapse of 84 years.

On
May 4, 2021
, a photograph depicting a moray eel caught in a river in Sri Lanka was forwarded to one of us (TR) for identification. Subsequently , efforts were made to gather additional details about the specimen. This specimen had been caught by hook and line using a shrimp as a bait by a fisherman at night in a deep pool on the Gin River immediately downstream of the bridge across the Gin River at Wakwella , Galle , ( 6°05’28.0”N 80°11’07.1”E ), about 4.8 km along the river from sea ( Fig. 1 ). It measured approximately 890 mm total length.

A sample of gill tissue was obtained from the dead specimen for DNA barcoding, employing partial mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase subunit 1 ( cox1 ). The procedures for DNA extraction, PCR amplification using the universal cox1 barcoding region and primers FishF2 and FishR1 (
Ward et al. 2005
) and sequencing are detailed in
Rüber et al. (2023)
. Subsequently, raw reads were processed and assembled into contigs using Geneious Prime v2022.0.2 (https:// www.geneious.com). Sequences in GenBank corresponding to cox1 and identified as
Gymnothorax polyuranodon
were retrieved from https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/ and aligned using MUSCLE ( Edgar 2004 ) within MEGA (
Kumar et al. 2016
). The alignment underwent scrutiny, and translation was conducted to confirm the absence of frameshift mutations and premature stop codons. MEGA was then utilized to compute uncorrected genetic distances (p-distances) among the sequences. In addition, a Neighbor-joining (NJ) tree based on HKY distances was generated using all the available cox1 sequences in GenBank identified as
Gymnothorax
(866 sequences downloaded on 19 Dec 2023 ).
Gymnomuraena zebra
(JN020361) was used as the outgroup. The resulting NJ tree is deposited on Dryad Digital Repository (https://doi. org/10.5061/dryad.6wwpzgn5n).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE. 1. (A) Records of
Gymnothorax polyuranodon
from Sri Lanka; (B) specimen of
G. polyuranodon
from downstream of Wakwella Dam, Gin River, approximately 890 mm in total length; and (C) close-up of head.

subSection.paragraph:
There were only four published cox1 sequences identified as
Gymnothorax polyuranodon
in GenBank. Two of these are from Fiji (accession numbers LC459595 and LC459596). These two sequences have a percentage identity of> 99% and an E-value of 0.0 with the Sri Lankan sample sequenced in the present study (GenBank accession number PP101023) and cluster together in the NJ tree. The uncorrected p-distance between the Sri Lankan sample of
G. polyuranodon
from these two sequences is only 0.2–0.5%. The other two (KF929936 and HQ122469) GenBank sequences identified as
Gymnothorax polyuranodon
are in fact misidentifications. These two sequences have an E-value of 0.0 and percentage identity> 98 % for
G. undulatus (Lacepède)
. These two sequences are also nested within the clade that represents
G. undulatus
in the NJ tree. The former sequence originates from Seychelles , while the locality of the latter is not known. These two sequences differ from the Sri Lankan sample by an uncorrected p distance of 17.5–19.1%.

Gymnothorax polyuranodon
is one of the most elusive freshwater fishes in Sri Lanka . Several freshwater fishes that were considered to be very rare or even extinct, such as
Labeo lankae
( Cyprinidae ) and
Macrognathus pentophthalmos
( Mastacembelidae ), have been rediscovered and redescribed in the recent past ( Pethiyagoda & Sudasinghe 2021 ;
Sudasinghe et al. 2018
). Three of the most rarely encountered fishes in Sri Lankan freshwaters are known to have a marine lifehistory phases ( Pethiyagoda & Sudasinghe 2021 ):
Kuhlia marginata (Cuvier)
( Kuhliidae ),
Stiphodon martenstyni Watson
( Gobiidae ) and
G. polyuranodon
( Muraenidae ). In all three cases, Sri Lanka seems to be the westernmost extremity of their ranges. In Sri Lanka , all three have been recorded from the perhumid south-western wet zone (rainfall> 2500 mm per year).
Kuhlia marginata
is reported from rocky, unshaded pools with fast flow just below waterfalls ( Pethiyagoda 1991 ). The present record of
G. polyuranodon
is only the third for this species from Sri Lanka . Our record is in some 7 km along the river from Dodangoda, from where Deraniyagala (1952) reported his second specimen ( Fig. 1A ). While
G. polyuranodon
has not been reported from any other country bordering the Bay of Bengal, all records of this species appear to be associated with rainforest habitats ( Pethiyagoda & Sudasinghe, 2021 ). If there is in fact an association with climate, perhaps as reflected in water quality, the distribution of
G. polyuranodon
could add another layer of complexity to the largely unknown life history of this species ( Pethiyagoda & Sudasinghe, 2021 ).

The rediscovery of
G. polyuranodon
after a lapse of 84 years in Sri Lanka leaves the sicydiine goby
Stiphodon martenstyni
, known from a single specimen also from the island’s perhumid southwest, as the island’s most elusive fish. It has not been recorded since the original collection from Atweltota on the Kalu River in 1981 ( Pethiyagoda & Sudasinghe, 2021 ).

HS is grateful to the Department of Wildlife Conservation for providing permits (permit no. WL/3/2/59/14, and WL/3/2/23/2023). HS and TR would like to thank Risira Randula, Sanjika, Sanoj Wijayasekara, Thaveesha de Alwis and Yashodara Athapaththu for informing us about the specimen through social media and organizing the logistics to obtain it. We are grateful for Brendan C. Ebner for commenting on the manuscript.
